title: Parents stage protests alongside striking teachers at troubled primary school - Manchester Evening News
text:
News Parents stage protests alongside striking teachers at troubled primary school Teachers kicked off six days of planned strike action at Bollin Primary in Bowdon today - but the school is open as usual after drafting in a raft of supply staff Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Parents at a troubled primary school have staged a protests alongside striking teachers. 
Today the union said 19 out of 20 teachers kicked off six days of planned strike action at Bollin Primary in Bowdon but the school is open as usual after drafting in a raft of supply staff. 
And parents who launched a petition against headteacher Michelle Brindle’s leadership are also staging their own protest outside the school. 
Those who started the online petition, which has gathered more than 750 signatures, say there has been “growing groundswell of outrage” at the way the school is being managed. Read More Trafford council warns Bollin Primary School as teachers plan strike action 
Tensions at the school are said to have deepened following the resignation of four governors in December. 
A separate faction of parents have spoken out in support of Mrs Brindle, arguing she is taking the school in the right direction but a planned protest supporting her failed to materialise. 
Thursday’s walk out centres around teachers’ workloads, ‘excessive scrutiny’ and an ‘obsession’ with data. 
Peter Middleman, regional secretary for the NUT, said: “Staff have been raising legitimate concerns since last autumn about workloads, excessive scrutiny and an obsession with the capture and manipulation of data relating to pupil progress which has become a significant impediment to good teaching and learning.” 
In a statement speaking out against strike action, parents in support of Mrs Brindle said: “We all love our school so let’s unite and leave the head teacher, senior management team, teachers and teaching assistants to sort out their professional issues without interference from parents. Bollin Primary School in Bowdon, where staff are due to go out on strike. (Photo: Manchester Evening News) Read More Some rail services cancelled as trains forced to halve speeds due to Storm Doris 
“There has been a lot of gossip, rumour, speculation and half-truths put out about the situation at school. This is now becoming extremely serious for our children’s future education, so we need to address the myths and look at the facts.” 
Headteacher Michelle Brindle added: “As head teacher, I am one hundred per cent committed to my position, the pupils and the team. I want to work alongside parents and the governors to make the school a happy and inspirational environment for both the children and staff.” 
NUT members will strike on Thursday, plus five more days of separate walk outs in February and March. Like us on Facebook
